Posts.Content: My husband wants another PSA test. I am so frustrated by this. His numbers have increased for last 5 years, doubling in past year. They have consistently increased. Dr felt a "scaly" patch on exam. His brother passed from this disease. He said he wants another PSA test, preferably from another lab, even if he has to pay for it. I can't understand his reasoning. Just get the darn biopsy. No matter what the PSA test result is, the dr told him to get a biopsy and also told him he suspects CA. My husband said the dr said that to "cover himself" which is crazy. The dr would only tell him and document that he suggested a biopsy, not give him his feeling on whether or not it is cancer to cover himself. My personal opinion is that he's in a bit of denial and only listening to those telling him that they had biopsies and were fine. He doesn't understand that just because he has no other symptoms that it doesn't mean he doesn't have cancer, just that it could be in an early stage. Any suggestions on this? Would another PSA test really be so different? Would it matter? Thank you. "A frustrated wife"~~~

Posts.Content: Thank you for your replies. We are getting second opinions from both radiation oncologists as well as surgeons. The department at the large university hospital 2 hours from us puts you in with both for second opinions. Appreciate the info on Patrick Walsh's book that it might have outdated material. I will jump on getting more up to date info. This forum is a wealth of information. Thank you so much.
Posts.Title: The results are in

Posts.Content: Thank you for your replies. We are getting second opinions from both radiation oncologists as well as surgeons. The department at the large university hospital 2 hours from us puts you in with both for second opinions. Appreciate the info on Patrick Walsh's book that it might have outdated material. Posts.Title: The results are in

Posts.Content: Prostate Cancer 3 of the 12 sites biopsied. This is all new so please excuse while I try to give you the info you need to help with decisions. Right Lateral Base: Invasive prostatic adenocarcinoma, Gleason scorte 6 (3+3) involving 2% of total biopsy material. No perineural invasion is present. Right Lateral Mid: Atypical Small Acinar Proliferation (ASAP) Left Lateral Base: Invasive prostatic adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 7 (3+4) involving 60% of total biopsiy material. No perineural invasion is present. Left Lateral Mid: INVASIVE prostatic adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 8 (4+4) involoving 10% of total biopsy material, no parineural invasion present. Rest came back benign. No malignancy present. He is being sent for CT scan and bone scan, and follow up with dr later this month. Then onto a second opinion, which the dr said his staff will set up for us. Dr stated he's been doing the surgery since 2009, has "done hundreds" and is chief of staff at the Urology center. He gave us good sites to go on for info (already been researching like crazy since we first had our PSA consult with him over a month ago) and reading the excellent book this site recommends. He will discuss all types of treatment plans with us at our next visit. He stressed that this is caught early, he's young (64) and in otherwise excellent health. He felt it could be very curable. Opinions and thoughts greatly appreciated and welcomed. Thank you.

Posts.Title: The results are in

Posts.Content: My husband is asking if there were any diet restrictions prior and after surgery. I do the reading on the forum and give him answers to his questions. I didn't see anything in particular regarding this, so anyone who would like to jump in please do so. We're aware that he'll probably want small light meals (soups) etc, but wondering if there is anything you'd like to add. Although tests and dr appts are scheduled for Jan with hopefully surgery late Jan-early Feb, he'd like a jump start on eating healthier in regards to prostate health. We know the surgeon will give him all the info he needs in regards to pre-post surgery, but asking for those who went before us is very beneficial. A side note...he is in very good, if not excellent health with this prostate cancer being the exception. He was on cholesteral meds for years but tried to keep his numbers down on his own. Lost weight, eats very healthy, but it's a hereditary disease and his numbers climbed up and he was told today to go back on it. Other than that, he is perfect weight. He does like dairy, which he's cut down on (yogurts, cottage cheese, regular cheeses) to every other day. Rarely red meat (had lasagna last month). Otherwise lots of fish, chicken, salads, fruits and veggies. Hardly any sweets. Thank you for any info you care to share.
Posts.Title: Has your diet changed?

Posts.Content: Thank you everyone. This is mostly what we expected to hear. I think he'll miss his coffee though!

Posts.Title: Has your diet changed?

Posts.Content: Upon doing a search I haven't found anyone on the forum from either of these areas. Does anyone have any info on drs, treatments, centers, hospitals that are recommended in these areas? Insurance will only allow us to stay in SC. MUSC in Charleston is a couple of hours away and unfortunately there's only one drs group on our plan. The dr we saw in MB seems very nice, knowledgeable and experienced. I believe he is the chief of staff at the hospital (at least his bio states he either was or is currently) BX scheduled end of Oct. We will go for a second opinion in Charleston. Thank you for any info.
Posts.Title: Myrtle Beach and Charleston Anyone?

Posts.Content: My husband is 2 1/2 weeks post nerve sparing RALP surgery. Dr prescribed 60mg of Sildenafil taken 3x a week. (20 mg tabs, he takes 3 at a time). Started last week. They sent a 30 day supply. Pharmacy said it will not be covered anymore than the initial 30 day supply. Where do you get your non covered meds from? I know this an important drug for rehabilitation of the penis and want to have dr write a script so we can get it someplace else. Please advise. Thank you.
Posts.Signature: Age 64 brother passed from PC age 57 PSA 4 12 core BX Oct 24, 2018 3 cores positive PC rt lateral base Gleason 3+3, 3+4, 4+4 Bone scan negative CT negative RALP Surgery March 9, 2018 T Stage: T2c Nerve sparing both sides Lymph nodes clear Margins clear
Posts.Title: Sildenafil

Posts.Content: My husband was diagnosed with PC exactly 6 months ago. 8 weeks ago he underwent RALP surgery. I did most of the research and we discussed all my findings in detail. He wanted the surgery from the beginning. He had a Gleason score of 8 which was considered advanced, but it was contained in the prostate and surgery was nerve sparing. We were confident in his surgeon and he is in excellent health and shape which Im sure helps. My husbands brother died from PC 12 years ago. I tell you this because of your fear having both your father and sister die so close together of VERY different and aggressive cancers. Thankfully, PC, caught timely, can be both treatable and curable. You were given excellent advice to get Dr Walshs book. I found it very helpful. Reading on this site was probably the most helpful though Anytime you hear the word cancer its scary and overwhelming. But by reading on this forum youll see many success stories. I wish you luck as you navigate through this. Stay positive.

Posts.Title: Sildenafil

Posts.Content: My husband had RALP surgery 6 weeks ago. Nerve sparing. Prior to surgery he had no erection and performance issues at all. We understand it could take a year or so for him to have feelings and erections again. However, he has no idea how the men on this board are achieving orgasm without an erection. He takes 100mg of Sildenafil 3x a week. He says that he wakes up around 4 am with a slight erection on the mornings after he takes the drug (he takes it mid day). But its semi hard, doesnt last, and although he tries to self stimulate he loses it quickly. He hasnt gotten any twinges for lack of a better word. Hes baffled on how to orgasm without getting hard. Anyone have advice, words of experience? Thank you
Posts.Signature: Age 64 brother passed from PC age 57 PSA 4 12 core BX Oct 24, 2018 3 cores positive PC rt lateral base Gleason 3+3, 3+4, 4+4 Bone scan negative CT negative RALP Surgery March 9, 2018 T Stage: T2c Nerve sparing both sides Lymph nodes clear Margins clear
Posts.Title: Post RALP ED questions.

Posts.Content: Thank you for your responses. I went to the Tena website and sent for a trial pack. Appreciate the feedback
Posts.Title: 6 days only for catheter removal

Posts.Content: My husband has asked me to give you a complete update on his RALP surgery to help all of you facing this. This site offered invaluable information to us and its our turn to give back. My husbands brother passed away fro PC (12 years ago) at age 57. My husband is turning 65. His PSA numbers were starting to rise and doubled in a year. This past Sept they were a 4. We went to an Urologist who suggested a BX stating he strongly suspected PC. BX late Oct and results in Nov showed cancer in 3 of the 12 cores at the base. Gleason score 3+3,3+4, and 4+4. My husband was only interested in surgery. He did research the radiation, but was clearly onboard with RALP surgery. In Jan he had the bone scan and CT scan all negative. Second opinion in late Jan followed by MRI and surgery was set for March 9th. Surgery went as planned. Dr stated that the cancer was contained to the prostate, margins clear, lymph nodes clear, and it was nerve sparing on both sides He was very sore and needed Tylenol about once or twice a day for about 4 days. He was able to sleep in bed and first 2 nights was fitful but after that was able to sleep on his side which allowed for a more restful night. Took stool softeners and laxatives as prescribed. Bowel movement in 3 days and back to normal now, but he does take the Colace 2x a day still Catheter wasnt too much of an issue for him. Never got sore but used Vaseline. It was taken out on day 6. He called the small bag Mr Foley Jr and the larger night bag Mr Foley Sr. He was very nervous to get it taken out but said it was nothing at all. Best thing to report so far is that he has absolutely no incontinence. None. Not a dribble. Hes on day 3 The only painful time was when they removed the drain from his side the day after surgery. He said it was a weird feeling and not pleasant. It lasted 5 seconds but listening to him you would think it lasted an hour. I was there. I dont even think it was 5 seconds. My husband was thrilled to say goodbye to Mr Foley Jr and Sr! Like all of you, he hopes and prays that Mr Woody makes a return appearance without much difficulty! If anyone has any questions please dont hesitate to ask. Like we said, this site and the men who share their experiences helped us so very much. Wed like to give back too.
Posts.Signature: Age 64 brother passed from PC age 57 PSA 4 12 core BX Oct 24, 2018 3 cores positive PC rt lateral base Gleason 3+3, 3+4, 4+4 Bone scan negative CT negative RALP Surgery March 9, 2018 T Stage: T2c Nerve sparing both sides Lymph nodes clear Margins clear

I plan on being as helpful as your wife. My your recovery continue to improve each day.

Posts.Title: Very upsetting 6 month PSA result post RALP

Posts.Content: My husband had RALP surgery 6 months ago. Cancer contained, no margins affected, nerves spared. 3 month checkup had a PSA of 0.02. Today we saw the dr but his PSA results werent back yet, but dr said they should be 0.02 or lower. Well, just got the test results which were sent to his auto chart and theyre 0.03. Call is into Dr but we are truly scared. Have any of you encountered this? Better to hear from real people. I was hoping hed be soon in the zero club. Please offer some insight. Thank you
Posts.Signature: Age 64 brother passed from PC age 57 PSA 4 12 core BX Oct 24, 2018 3 cores positive PC rt lateral base Gleason 3+3, 3+4, 4+4 Bone scan negative CT negative RALP Surgery March 9, 2018 T Stage: T2c Nerve sparing both sides Lymph nodes clear Margins clear
Posts.Title: Very upsetting 6 month PSA result post RALP

Posts.Content: I know many of you use the surgeons at large facilities such as Mayo Clinic, Sloan, Cleveland Center, Duke, etc, but we have to stay in our state of SC due to insurance limitations. We are 2 hours from Charleston (MUSC) where our local surgeon is sending us for a second opinion. My husband likes the local surgeon and is comfortable with him. He seems patient and so far we like his bedside manner and the way he deals with us. Have any of you used local surgeons that haven't performed thousands of surgeries? Our local surgeon (who is chief of staff at the center) told us he has performed "hundreds" since 2009, but as another forum member pointed out, over an 8 year span that really isn't a lot. Just curious as to your thoughts. My husband's Gleason score was an 8. 3 cores of 12 were cancerous. One a 6, one a 7, one an 8. CT scans and bone scans being performed this week. Thank you for your help.
Posts.Title: Criteria for choosing Surgeon

Posts.Content: Thank you for the replies and detailed answers. I questioned my husband again as to exactly what did the dr say. First, we both agree that he was pleasant, thorough and patient. We did not get the feeling he was pompous and full of himself. We did get the impression that he was experienced and knowledgeable. My husband doesn't think he used the term "make no mistake" as I thought he did. He can't remember exact wording, but it was after I told him I really thought he was going to suggest waiting that he made "a comment" in regards that this probably is cancer and he would not wait on having a biopsy. As for the re-scheduling it's not possible. First opening is late Oct. Next available late Nov. He performs biopsies one day every other week. We will go for second (and possibly third) opinions at larger city hospitals. MUSC is 2 hours away.

He is meeting with an acquaintance next week who had the surgery several years ago. So glad to hear your pain was minimal and you didn't need meds other than Tylenol. I plan on being as helpful as your wife. My your recovery continue to improve each day.
Posts.Title: 3rd morning post RALP surgery

Posts.Content: My husband had the DaVinci surgery this past Friday. They scheduled the catheter removal for this Thurs. I read the discharge papers and it says 6-7 days. I also called to verify. I thought most of you state you get it taken out at 10 days. Just curious Also, can you be specific in what pads you used? I assume Depends at first but what exactly did you use after? Thank you His surgery went very well. Dr took lymph nodes out because the cancer was a more aggressive type but he was confident that it was contained to prostate. We will know definitively when path report comes back He told my husband the next morning that he did spare the nerves. So far hes had stomach pain due to incisions and is up walking around the house as instructed by dr. He did have his first BM but not a great one and is really ready to go again! Hes on stool softeners and the anti spasmatic for the bladder All in all I think hes doing great!
Posts.Title: 6 days only for catheter removal

Posts.Content: How far away have some of you traveled? Were there complications when returning home?
Posts.Title: Criteria for choosing Surgeon

Posts.Content: Well, not a club my husband wants to be a part of, but here we (probably) are. This is all new to us. I've been reading this forum like crazy last few days and ordered a book that was suggested here as well. Here's our story: Husband is 64. His brother died from Prostate cancer which was detected at age 50 (passed age 57). My husband's PSA has gradually increased last few years. from 1.5, 2, 3. The dr had him come back in 6 months after the reading of 3 and it jumped now to 4. She referred him to a Urologist. We weren't worried, just concerned and figured the Urologist would probably do a wait and see. Maybe redo the PSA in 6 months. We went to the appt and we liked the dr very much. He was very matter of fact. He did an exam and told him that the right area felt scaly. He said in all of his years practicing he could usually feel a lump and did not feel that with him. Of course, cancer could be on the underside. Anyway, he suggested a biopsy. He said insurances don't cover MRI's (true, ours doesn't, I checked). I told him I thought we could wait a little and he looked at us and said, "make no mistake, you have cancer. It's now getting a biopsy so it's caught at an early stage before progression". We stumbled out of there (after he nicely made small talk about his daughter and where she was going to college). Anyone I mention his name to says he's great. Found out he's Chief of Staff at our hospital. Which isn't the greatest hospital...I'm a couple of hours from larger hospital but he is well respected so for now we'll have biopsy with him. It's scheduled late Oct. I will come back after results are in and go from there. I appreciate the willingness I am seeing in so many of you to help us newbies out. I am researching different treatments and getting second opinions. Also read on the sticky about sending path results to be read by John Hopkins. All of this will be researched in depth as the weeks go on. One quick question: We have a family wedding that we have to drive 9 hours to only 3 days after biopsy. Surgical nurse told us no problem but drs nurse said absolutely no sitting for that long and no driving. Opinions please? We might have to postpone biopsy 2 weeks. Your opinion on that as well is great appreciated. Again, thank you.
Posts.Title: Another new member here

Posts.Content: My husband is 5 1/2 months post nerve sparing surgery. No incontinence but experiencing ED. Takes Sildenafil 3x a week. Was taking 60mg and dr at 3 month checkup told him to take 100 mg. After much manual stimulation can get harder, but not enough for penetration. Has climaxed, but very difficult to achieve. Prior to surgery had no problem in this area at all. Question wed like to ask is that hes experiencing nocturnal erections few times a week. They wake him up and last a few minutes, even if he massages area. In your experience, does this mean hes more likely to have sustainable erections return? Hes being patient, but I know hes so frustrated and disappointed. We go back to dr in one month. Thank you. Just wanted to hear from real people who experienced this.
Posts.Signature: Age 64 brother passed from PC age 57 PSA 4 12 core BX Oct 24, 2018 3 cores positive PC rt lateral base Gleason 3+3, 3+4, 4+4 Bone scan negative CT negative RALP Surgery March 9, 2018 T Stage: T2c Nerve sparing both sides Lymph nodes clear Margins clear

Posts.Content: Thank you. He really needs to know there’s hope. At the same time, he says regularly that being cancer free is the most important

Posts.Title: Personal question regarding ED after DaVinci surgery

Posts.Content: My husband went to Urologist late Sept. Biopsy was late Oct. Results Nov 1st. 3 cores positive, Gleason 6, 7 and 8. Urologist stated he's sending him for CT scan (tomorrow) and bone scan Fri, with f/u with him next week. 2nd opinion scheduled end of month. Dr felt cancer is contained, that bone scan is precautionary. He said we have plenty of time to make decisions, but not to wait longer than 6 months. CT scan will cost $1000. The hospital hasn't notified us cost of bone scan. In January, our costs will be substantially reduced. He wants to wait. What is your honest opinion? What would you do?
Posts.Title: Need an answer ASAP on this please

Posts.Content: Thank you for quickly responding. I do recall reading you need to wait 6 weeks for surgery. In that case, as you pointed out, waiting till Jan for the scans, f/u and 2nd opinion would be ok. I am sure you all experienced something similar in that this is your new normal. Trying to educate ourselves and make smart prudent decisions. Your help is so appreciated.
Posts.Title: Need an answer ASAP on this please

Posts.Content: My husband went to Urologist late Sept. Biopsy was late Oct. Results Nov 1st. 3 cores positive, Gleason 6, 7 and 8. Urologist stated he's sending him for CT scan (tomorrow) and bone scan Fri, with f/u with him next week. 2nd opinion scheduled end of month. Dr felt cancer is contained, that bone scan is precautionary. He said we have plenty of time to make decisions, but not to wait longer than 6 months. CT scan will cost $1000. The hospital hasn't notified us cost of bone scan. In January, our costs will be substantially reduced. He wants to wait. What is your honest opinion? What would you do?
Posts.Title: Need an answer ASAP on this please

Posts.Content: Thank you for quickly responding. I do recall reading you need to wait 6 weeks for surgery. In that case, as you pointed out, waiting till Jan for the scans, f/u and 2nd opinion would be ok. I am sure you all experienced something similar in that this is your new normal. Trying to educate ourselves and make smart prudent decisions. Your help is so appreciated.
Posts.Title: Need an answer ASAP on this please

Posts.Content: I will add his history to my signature so all info is present. His Gleason was 6. (3+3) 7 (3+4) 8 (4+4) All tests, follow ups and 2nd opinions rescheduled for early-mid Jan. Although a price tag can't be put on one's life, the difference in waiting till early-mid Jan is $14,000. Surgery, which is route he is most likely going with, can't be performed until late Dec at the earliest. Therefore, waiting the additional 4-6 weeks for surgery is most likely not going to make a tremendous difference. His PSA scores were going up last 4-5 years. Dec 2015 was a 2. Feb 2017 they were 3 and Sept 1st they were a 4. The numbers doubled in a year plus his brother died from PC at age 58. Diagnosed at age 50. No one knows any info on him in regards to PSA numbers, how diagnosed, etc since his wife has passed as well. My husband is 64 and in excellent health and on no medications. Excellent weight as well. No problems with biopsy. Again, thank you for all responses.
